Copie of my l
re
to my L. T
re
r 19 Oc
t
95.
Whereas I am enjoyed to
ceede w
t
out admitting anie
dilatorie answear, I protest unto yo
r
L. I know not in
e
world how to doe it more effectually, then I have put in tryal
having done in
t
behalf both in publicke and in privat, as
fol.293r
must as is possible, and more by much then is ex
p
ssed in any point
of my instructions, as well by speciall
suasions, as by other
insinuations of danger to
e c
o
trey: in so much as I have
doubted in mine owne privat judgem
e
t, whether I kept in
t
decor
u
, in regard of
e dignitie and state of her
M
ie
to insist
so earnestly, so often, so many sundry wayes, w
t
a people of
this condition, and so much bound unto her H
es
. And therefore
not
p
vailing w
t
so great importunity I could wade no further
w
t
them, but certify by l
re
s, how I founde their dispositions.
But since
e receite of yo
r
L. letter,
e
Councell of Estate
being
come home to
e Hage, up
o
e writing of
e
States,
I laboured
w
at
I could to
cure their advise to be p
nt
ly given: but getting
notice under hand,
t
their drift was altogether, to sende unto
her M
ie
(as I have allwayes thought they would) to cutte of
all occ
ao
ns of further delayes, I lette them flatly underst
a
d,
and w
t
all I made it knowen to
e college of
e States,
t
if so
be they had no meaning to satisfie her H
es
but would
happely determine to sende some Deputies unto her, to deli-
ver theyr excuses, they should alter
t
intent, and keepe
theyr Deputies at home: for so I had bin willed to signifie
unto them. This was taken much to hart,
t
her M
ie
would refuse in a cause of
t
mom
e
t, to give th
e
e hearing:
and both
e States and
e Councell have c
o
sulted very often
for divers dayes together, w
at
course to take upon it. For
to forbeare to sende at all, they thought it might be taken
for a weake resol
uo
n, sith they could not by their l
re
s
make so cleare a dem
o
str
ao
n of their w
a
t of ready meanes,
to give her M
ie
c
o
tentm
e
t, and to
p
vent therew
t
all the
effectes of her displeasure, as by
e verbals of those
t
might
be purposely sent about it: whome they hoped
t
her H
nes
upon theire sute in
t
behalfe would be willing to admitte.
And yet to sende upon
p
sumption, when they had bin by
me forewarned to refrayne, and so
haps, when they came,
to be rejected of her M
ie
they thought it would be caried
fol.293v
over all partes of Christendome, and move
e multitude
heere, who might thinke they were forsaken, to accept
of such conditions as
e Peacemakers offer.
When I presse them somewhat neere in privat c
o
vers
ao
n,
to tell me, how they can
p
vent
e subversion of their State,
if her M
ie
should
test and w
t
drawe her assistance, theyr
answear savoureth altogether of a desperat moode. Loth,
they say, they would be to c
o
test w
t
her H
es
and will sh
u
ne
it, as they may, in all dutifull sorte,
t
e Enemy may not
triumphe, and turne it to his benefit: but if she force them
unto it, by her publicke
testaons, they have but to much
to alleage, both to justifie themselves in
e sight of the
world, and to notifie to all men, w
t
w
at
patience they
have boren
e breaches of
e c
o
tract exceeding greatly to
theyr
p
judice: And if w
t
all shee will
ceede to deprive
them of her aide, they must, and will
vide to trust unto
themselves, and to such helpes, as God shall sende, it having
bin ever theyr destinie to deffende their libertie and
rightes w
t
adversity and troubles. But if otherwise then
well should befalle their estate, it would be seene but
oversoone
t
Englandes
staffe standeth next
e doare.
I call to minde many times
t
her M
ie
in her speeches
of
e affaires of these c
o
treis, hath seemed often so to build
up
o
e affections of this people, as if
e Generality were
more addicted to c
o
tent her, then this assembly of
their Deputies, and
t
e inhabitants of
e Townes might be
drawen by rem
o
strance to refourme and disavowe
e dea-
lings of their Delegates. This was so out of
q
stion
at
e making of
e C
o
tract, and so c
o
tinued somew
at
after,
untill they grewe out of liking w
t
some courses,
t
were
held by some Ministers of her M
tie
, and reduced their estate
to some better forme of government. But for these 6 or 7
fol.294r
years, I have found
e people very willing to be guided by
their Deputies, who are also very warie to know how farre
they may
p
sume. For though somw
at
sometimes be done by
their Deputies against their humors and opinions, yet it is but
very seldome in maters of mom
e
t: and I could never yet
observe
t
there was any thing c
o
trolled or c
o
termanded by the
people,
t
they had once ordained: w
c
is
e patience they will use,
for
p
serv
ao
n of their uni
o
, whereof I thought it not amisse
to touche a worde unto yo
r
L. if happly some course of
posing maters to
e com
o
s, should seeme expedi
e
t for her M
tie
.
